articles.headline: Hedge Fund Calls New York Times Article a ‘Distortion’
articles.snippet: Ray Dalio, the chairman of Bridgewater Associates, said the article, which reported on the culture at the hedge fund, contained “significant mischaracterizations.”
articles.abstract: Ray Dalio, the chairman of Bridgewater Associates, said the article, which reported on the culture at the hedge fund, contained “significant mischaracterizations.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Bridgewater Associates, the world’s largest hedge fund, released a statement on Thursday taking issue with what it called “significant mischaracterizations” and a “distortion” of some of its business practices and culture that were described in an article in The New York Times.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: Democrats Eager to Woo Republicans Who Are Wary of Trump
articles.snippet: The convention in Philadelphia was a carefully calibrated assault on the Republican coalition, designed to welcome voters unwilling to vote for Donald J. Trump.
articles.abstract: The convention in Philadelphia was a carefully calibrated assault on the Republican coalition, designed to welcome voters unwilling to vote for Donald J. Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — They saluted the valor and vigor of the American armed forces. They quoted Ronald Reagan and Theodore Roosevelt, iconic Republican presidents of the 20th century, as well as a beloved Republican former first lady. They talked plainly about faith, about instilling good family values, about the uniqueness of the American experiment.

articles.headline: In Hillary Clinton’s Nomination, Women See a Collective Step Up
articles.snippet: In interviews, women across the country said they believed that a female presidency could be a force in their own lives, even if they did not yet know how.
articles.abstract: In interviews, women across the country said they believed that a female presidency could be a force in their own lives, even if they did not yet know how.
articles.lead_paragraph: The president would know what it is like to be pregnant. Top military leaders would answer to a female boss, when there has never even been a woman on the Joint Chiefs of Staff. Workplaces and home life could be transformed through expanded parental leave and pay equity. Or nothing could change. The symbolism would be supernova-level. The backlash could be withering.

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton Warns of ‘Moment of Reckoning’ in Speech Accepting Nomination
articles.snippet: Mrs. Clinton urged voters to unite against the divisive policy ideas and combative politics of Donald J. Trump.
articles.abstract: Mrs. Clinton urged voters to unite against the divisive policy ideas and combative politics of Donald J. Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Hillary Diane Rodham Clinton, who sacrificed personal ambition for her husband’s political career and then rose to be a globally influential figure, became the first woman to accept a major party’s presidential nomination on Thursday night, a prize that generations of American women have dreamed about for one of their own.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Amy Chozick

articles.headline: In Tribute to Son, Khizr Khan Offered Citizenship Lesson at Convention
articles.snippet: In a speech that included displaying a copy of the Constitution, a father rebuked Donald J. Trump and gave voice to Muslim Americans.
articles.abstract: In a speech that included displaying a copy of the Constitution, a father rebuked Donald J. Trump and gave voice to Muslim Americans.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Capt. Humayun Khan was ordered to Iraq a dozen years ago, his father wanted to talk to him about being an American Muslim soldier sent to war in a Muslim country.

articles.headline: Disappointing 2nd-Quarter Growth, Despite Strong Consumer Spending
articles.snippet: The data was only a slight improvement from the first quarter and showed how weaker government outlays held back growth, reinforcing a trend that has hobbled the recovery in recent years.
articles.abstract: The data was only a slight improvement from the first quarter and showed how weaker government outlays held back growth, reinforcing a trend that has hobbled the recovery in recent years.
articles.lead_paragraph: The economic recovery may be durable, but it is anything but dynamic.

articles.headline: After Yemeni’s 13 Years in Guantánamo, Freedom for the Soul Takes Longer
articles.snippet: Ahmed Abdul Qader, released a year and a half ago, said: “I cannot live my life regularly. I try, but it is like part of me is still at Guantánamo.”
articles.abstract: Ahmed Abdul Qader, released a year and a half ago, said: “I cannot live my life regularly. I try, but it is like part of me is still at Guantánamo.”
articles.lead_paragraph: TALLINN, Estonia — When guards brought Ahmed Abdul Qader to the plane that would take him away from the Guantánamo Bay prison a year and a half ago, he asked permission to pause before boarding. Closing his eyes, he tried to leave behind the burden of his 13 years of captivity.

articles.headline: A Power Broker Who Wants Labor at the Table, Not on the Menu
articles.snippet: Lee Saunders, president of the biggest unions in the United States, has become an increasingly important voice in Washington. But that may no longer have the same currency it once did.
articles.abstract: Lee Saunders, president of the biggest unions in the United States, has become an increasingly important voice in Washington. But that may no longer have the same currency it once did.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The person at the center of defusing arguably the most contentious issue facing Democrats on the eve of their convention in Philadelphia was not a Hillary Clinton adviser or even a party operative. It was Lee Saunders, president of the 1.6-million-member American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees.

articles.headline: Parents Deserve a College Graduation Present, Too
articles.snippet: In Korean-American families, children give their parents gifts when they start their first job or graduate from college. This is why you might also want to be buying gifts for your parents.
articles.abstract: In Korean-American families, children give their parents gifts when they start their first job or graduate from college. This is why you might also want to be buying gifts for your parents.
articles.lead_paragraph: At this time of year, college graduates start their new lives and tally up their gifts. A personalized flask, perhaps. A newspaper subscription. Maybe something strong to drink after reading this summer’s mind-boggling headlines.

articles.headline: Gloomy Days in the Oil Patch, but Some See a Glimmer of Light
articles.snippet: Because of slumping world demand and a glut of global supply, oil players are still struggling to cope with the industry’s doldrums.
articles.abstract: Because of slumping world demand and a glut of global supply, oil players are still struggling to cope with the industry’s doldrums.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — As recently as two summers ago, Latshaw Drilling was so fully booked it sometimes had to turn away oil companies eager to rent one of its 39 rigs at $22,000 a day.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and Stanley Reed
